entry.title: SAP Document AI accelerates document-centric business processes with Generative AI
entry.content:
Authors: @amagnani37 & @merza 

Thank you to everyone who joined our recent partner webinar, "Streamline document processing with SAP Document AI". This session was part of our ongoing partner webinar series, "Talk to your business with Generative AI", and the turnout and engagement were fantastic.

For those who couldn't make it, or for anyone who wants a recap, we—Merza Klaghstan, Alice Magnani, and Jacob Tan from the BTP & AI Solution Architects team —wanted to share the key takeaways, demos, and technical insights from the session.

Our goal was to go beyond a simple feature list and show you how SAP Document AI can be the centerpiece of a complete, end-to-end business solution.

Here’s what we covered.

Part 1: What is SAP Document AI and Why Does it Matter?

We kicked off by tackling the core business problem: a staggering 70-80% of all enterprise information is unstructured. Manually processing this data from documents, emails, and scans is not only slow but also expensive and prone to errors.

SAP Document AI, formerly known as Document Information Extraction (DOX), is SAP's AI-powered solution on the Business Technology Platform (BTP) designed to solve this. It goes far beyond simple Optical Character Recognition (OCR) to extract, classify, and validate data with high precision.

Key Capabilities

We highlighted several key features:

  • Multiple Editions: The service is available in Base AI, Premium AI (which includes Generative AI capabilities), and Embedded editions to fit different use cases. We also want to highlight for our SAP Partners that the Premium AI edition is part of the Test, Demo, and Development (TDD) license, which provides a much more convenient model for your non-productive and internal development purposes.

     

  • The New "Workspace" UI: We compared the classic "Basic" UI with the new, full-featured "Workspace," which is the future of the service and includes capabilities like email channel configuration and workflow management.

    It's the new, full-featured environment for all document processing tasks . We want to emphasize that from now on, all the latest SAP Document AI features will be available in the Workspace UI only, so we strongly advise using it for all new projects.

     

  • Pre-Configured & Custom Content (Schemas): The service provides many pre-trained models (called "Schemas") for standard documents like invoices and purchase orders. The real power, however, comes from creating custom schemas for any document type your business needs—from specialized licenses to internal forms.

     

  • Generative AI & Instant Learning: For custom schemas, SAP Document AI leverages Generative AI and Large Language Models (LLMs) to understand and extract information. We also demonstrated "Instant Learning," where the model learns from your manual corrections immediately. After one correction, it knows how to handle that document layout correctly the next time.

    In our demo, we showed how the model initially struggled with a name containing a middle name and extracted the wrong federation name (full name vs. acronym) . After one manual correction and confirmation, it learned immediately. Technically, this feature uses few-shots prompting to make the underlying LLM aware of your previously reviewed documents to improve accuracy on the next run.

Part 2: A Real-World Use Case: "Vertigo Travels"

To make this real, we introduced "Vertigo Travels," a fictional travel agency specializing in sports and adventure holidays. Their key challenge is managing the various kind of documents required for subscriptions, such as ID cards, medical certificates, and diving licenses.

The solution architecture includes:

  1. The Vertigo Travels website, a frontend application,  deployed in Cloud Foundry, serving as entry point for Travelers to select travel packages and upload the necessary documents, such as ID cards or medical certificates. The backend logic is a CAP (Node.js) application also deployed in a cloud Foundry.

  2. SAP Document AI, for all document intelligence operations, communicating via API with our backend application.

  3. SAP HANA Cloud, as a persistence layer for our application, to store all the entities involved in the subscription process.

  4. SAP Build Work Zone standard edition, as the entry point for Vertigo Travels employees to supervise the process. From Work Zone, business users can access the Vertigo Travel website for admin operations, or the SAP Document AI workspace, for instance to review documents. SAP Build Work Zone also allows business users to use SAP Document AI via mobile.

  5. SAP Build Process Automation, to define business rules to automate some document validation checks. Although this could also be implemented as part of the  Vertigo Travels backend application, SAP Build Process Automation enables citizen developers to modify easily the business logics when required.

  6. SAP S/4HANA Cloud, as the core SAP Cloud solution. The Vertigo Travels backend is integrated with modules such as Business Partners, Products, Sales Orders/Invoice, Customer Return for refund.

For the source code, you may refer here for reference.

P.S. if you're planning to work on this prototype, please give us a shout out~! So at least we know somebody is trying our repository out!

We demonstrated three end-to-end scenarios:

  1. The E2E Flow: A traveler, Mary, subscribes on the website and uploads her documents. A back-office employee, Barry, reviews and corrects one document in the Document AI Workspace. Once confirmed, a Sales Order is automatically created in S/4HANA Cloud.

  2. Multi-Channel Ingestion: A traveler, Luca, visits an office. The employee uses SAP Mobile Start to scan his ID and medical certificate. The system then automatically emails Luca about a missing document. He simply replies to the email with his license attached, which is automatically ingested via the Inbound Channel feature.

  3. Automation: A traveler, Claire, uploads an income statement to apply for a discount. SAP Build Process Automation runs a rule to check her eligibility. When she submits her final documents, they have a high confidence score and are auto-confirmed without any manual review.

Part 3: How We Built It (The Technical Deep Dive)

For our developer community, we walked through the "how-to" for the key components.

For the source code, you may refer here for reference.

P.S. if you're planning to work on this prototype, please give us a shout out~! So at least we know somebody is trying our repository out!

1. Setup and Schema Management: We started with the BTP setup, which involves managing entitlements, creating the service instance, and, critically, establishing trust with SAP Cloud Identity Service (IAS) for user authorization. We then showed how to create the custom schemas that power the application.

When you set up your entitlements, make sure to use the application subscription ending in -ias (Identity Authentication Service), as this is the one that provisions the new Workspace interface.

2. API-Driven Development: Our CAP application's backend communicates directly with Document AI's APIs. We showed code snippets for uploading a file (using the FileService) and processing it against a schema (using the SchemaService).

How to retrieve specific extracted values:
While our demo UI showed a simple text extraction, your application will likely need specific, structured data (like "gross_family_income" or "number_of_kids"). The API makes this straightforward:

    • After processing the document, you get a Document ID.
    • You can use this Document ID to retrieve the Document Version ID.
    • Using the Version ID, you can then query the Entities for that document. 4. Finally, you can retrieve the specific value by using the Entity ID (e.g., the ID for your "number_of_kids" field) .

This is how our automation process, for example, was able to pull only the family income and number of kids to pass to the rules engine.

3. Configuring Email Ingestion: We configured the "Channels" feature to monitor an email inbox. This required registering an app in Microsoft Azure, granting Mail.ReadWrite permissions , and then using the Document AI Workspace to map a specific email folder to our target schema.

4. Enabling SAP Mobile Start: This was a key integration for the in-office scenario. It involved three steps:

    • Adding the Document AI dependency to SAP Build Work Zone within the IAS console.
    • Creating a specific BTP destination (sapdocumentaimobilestartintegration).
    • Configuring the app tile in the Work Zone Site Manager with the correct navigation and visualization parameters (e.g., mobilestart.type = documentAi).

4. Automating Logic with SAP Build Process Automation: To keep our application logic flexible, we externalized our validation rules. We created a process in SAP Build Process Automation with a Decision Table (Rule) to calculate the family discount based on income and number of kids. This process is exposed as an API and triggered by our CAP application.

For the source code, you may refer here for reference.

P.S. if you're planning to work on this prototype, please give us a shout out~! So at least we know somebody is trying our repository out!

Part 4: Conclusion, Best Practices, and What's Next

We concluded with some key advice and a look ahead.

Best Practices & Responsible AI

  • Quality In, Quality Out: The accuracy of extraction heavily depends on the quality of your scans.
  • Human in the Loop: While automation is powerful, always design your processes with a "human in the loop" for validation, especially for critical data.
  • Responsible AI: We reiterated SAP's commitment to AI ethics. External LLM providers are carefully selected and are not permitted to store or retrain their models on customer data. Features like continuous data sharing for model improvement are strictly opt-in and should not be used for sensitive personal data.

Get Started and Look Ahead

We are committed to helping our partners build on this platform. Here are the resources to get you started:

  • SAP Document AI Official Help Page: https://url.sap/imohkv
  • Vertigo Travels GitHub Repository: https://url.sap/pi5vwn (The code for our demo app will be available here!)
  • SAP Community for AI/ML: https://url.sap/ai-ml-grp

The roadmap for SAP Document AI is packed with features, including more pre-built schemas, document workflows, custom LLM prompting, and deeper integration with Joule.

Finally, don't miss SAP TechEd Virtual! Be sure to check out sessions AI821v and AI102v for the latest roadmap and deep-dive innovations from the product team.

Please feel free to leave any questions or feedback in the comments below!

entry.title: Getting Started with IoT in SAP Asset Performance Management
entry.content:
Getting Started with IoT in SAP Asset Performance Management

Introduction

With the latest release 2510 of SAP Asset Performance Management (APM), major features in the context of device connectivity and management were enabled and are available as part of the Early Adopter Care (EAC) program. These features utilize the embedded IoT capabilities powered by Cumulocity.

Only two months after its introduction in version 2506 (see also this blog article describing the initial release), many IoT centric features such as direct integration support for OT (operations technology) protocols like OPC-UA, real-time data ingestions via MQTT and REST, live dashboards, streaming analytics and advanced software- and firmware management of devices are now available to SAP Asset Performance Management customers as part of the EAC program.

To celebrate this milestone, we wanted to share a series of how-to guides with you.

In this guide it will be demonstrated how a device can be easily connected to the embedded IoT Platform (Cumulocity) and allocate their timeseries data to assets in SAP Asset Performance Management. It can be seen as a retrofit case where a smart sensor is added and can be attached and correlated to existing assets.

If you are looking for a more advanced way to connect industrial machines and devices to SAP Asset Performance Management, stay tuned for the next guide where we will leverage OPC-UA. We will also dive into applications for Streaming Analytics, how they work differently than existing APM rules and how to combine the strengths of both analytics engines for best results.

Prerequisites

To follow this guide, the following prerequisites must be fulfilled:

  • You have access to an SAP Asset Performance Management environment with Embedded IoT platform
  • You have a smartphone (iOS or Android)

Step-by-Step Guide

Download and Install the Cumulocity Sensor App

To get started, first of all we need a smartphone to install the Cumulocity Sensor App. It is available on the following stores:

  • Google Play Store: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.softwareag.cumulocity.iotcloudsensor
  • Apple App Store: https://apps.apple.com/us/app/cumulocity-iot-sensor-app/id1516838930 

Connect the App to Your Tenant

As a next step you can go to your provided Cumulocity Tenant → Cockpit App and hit the button "Connect smartphone". A wizard will guide you through the steps to scan a QR code with the app. In the final step of the wizard, you can click on "Open Device" to jump to the dashboard that has been created for your smartphone. 

 

Review Dashboard

In the default dashboard created for your smartphone, you can already see a Iot of useful things including:

  • The location of your device
  • Acceleration sensor values
  • Luxometer of your camera
  • Signal Strength and many more
 

 

Creating Indicators in SAP Asset Performance Management

With the data in Cumulocity you can now focus on assigning it to technical objects in SAP Asset Performance Management. In our case, we assume that the phone is attached to a "Cooling Water Circulation Pump" but you can assign it to any other asset of your choice. The acceleration sensor is used to detect vibration, similar to a retrofit sensor with a separate mobile uplink.

As a next step, we need to create indicators that represent our acceleration measurements. Follow the SAP documentation to create indicators for your selected asset.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP APM/8c95dca44fda4d56a17f6494f421758d/0b68eeb8daab49b2ac042ae90955e51f.html?locale=en-US&version=LATEST

Finally, copy the ID of the technical object you want to use for the further steps. It's displayed under the name of the asset in the top left corner.

Assign Data Points to Indicators

Navigate to the Embedded IoT platform, via the "Manage Devices" tile on the SAP Asset Performance Management Launchpad. Within the platform, switch to the "Digital Twin Manager" application via the top right application picker.

Since assets in SAP Asset Performance Management are automatically synced with the Embedded IoT platform, we can search in the Digital Twin Manager for the technical object ID you have copied in the last step to find the corresponding asset in Digital Twin Manager.

Select the asset and navigate to the "Data points" tab. Here you see all indicators as data points. Click on "Link source" and select the data point of your smartphone and demonstrate it on the screen below. Repeat the steps for the two other data points.

 

After successful assignment, the measurement data will be made available within SAP Asset Performance Management.

Review data in SAP Asset Performance Management

Back in SAP Asset Performance Management, we can navigate to our selected technical object and check if data is already available.

To view the indicators in SAP Asset Performance Management, select them for monitoring like demonstrated below.

Great, you have the data of your retrofit sensor successfully assigned to your technical object and can leverage SAP Asset Performance Management to use it for further use cases.

Conclusion & Next Steps

This guide demonstrated how you can quickly integrate a device to Embedded IoT powered by Cumulocity and assign its measurement data to an existing technical object in SAP Asset Performance Management.

In the next guide, we will use OPC-UA to integrate an industrial device to Cumulocity with multiple data points and assign it to an asset.

entry.title: Re: Automatic bank statement import for Japanese banks in...
entry.content:
Good day @byd 

Thank you for your question.

You can consult Processing Bank Statements for further details.

Here is a summary to your various questions:

Answer to question 1:

Automatic inbound import is not an out of the box solution in public cloud. The recommendation is a Multi-Bank Connectivity solution. See Overview on Automatic Bank Statement Processing and similar question for more information.

Without MBC, you can manually or programmatically use the Fiori apps/APIs to import files. Manage Bank Statements provides more insight.

To summarise, for true automation, I suggest you use SAP MBC or a partner channel that can push files to MBC or your middleware. Otherwise, use the Japan import apps or Manage Incoming Payment Files with a file feed that you trigger. See Integration with SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity for more details.

Answer to question 2:

Regarding Connectivity and formats for Japan, public cloud provides specific import apps that support ZENGINGKYO formats and Zengin XML. See more at KBA 3539536. SWIFT MT940/ISO 20022 camt.052/053/054 is fully supported as electronic bank statement formats in public cloud. You can achieve SFTP/host-to-host through MBC or through your middleware.

Answer to question 3:

You can activate J77, 1EG and 4X8 and use the Manage Incoming Payments Files or Manage Bank Statements apps to set it up.

 

Regarding your 4th. quetion, based on my experience there has been multiple successful implementation cases.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: EWM: How to configure free choice of Handling Unit?
entry.content:
Hi, 

Within our warehouse, we're using an overflow area. The overflow area is used only when the storage capacity for our regular bulk storage has reached its limits. The overflow area is a general storage area.

At the moment, the system suggests a handling unit, upon which our logistics employees have to search for the specific handling unit within overflow. However, sometimes this process is very time consuming as the employee not only has to look for the specific handling unit, but also has to move different handling units to reach the desired handling unit.

In SPRO, we have configured the following:

According to Performance Assistance, we've set 'Level of Avail. Qty. to '1'.

Our config. for Putaway Control

Our config. for Stock Removal Control, Goods Movement Control & Replenishment

We have tested this setting multiple times, but unfortunately, the system does not allow the employee to scan a desired handling unit. It either suggests a handling unit or it completely removes the HU-field in RFUI.

We want our employees to have a free choice in scanning the desired handling unit. So, the system should not suggest a handling unit. How do we configure this?

entry.title: Automatic Replenishment of remaining capacities
entry.content:
Hello all,

could someone help me with the automatic replenishment of remaining capacities for a workday in the tabular planning board in SAP ERP 6.0?

Example: The remaining capacity according to transaction cm50 of capacity type 001 (machine) of some machine on day A is 2 hours, also 2 hours on day B, and 6 hours on day C.

Let's assume that MRP generates a capacity requirement of 12 hours on day D, and the capacity on day D is 20 hours.

Now the challenge: How can I automatically ensure that when SAP draws on the 12-hour capacity requirement of a planned order (created from MRP) on day D, it first uses the remaining capacity from days A, B, and C (i.e., 10 hours total) before drawing the remaining 2 hours from the 20 hours on day D?

Which settings in the strategy profile, workplace, etc., ensure that capacity is always automatically replenished to 100% utilization of a given capacity type?

 

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Issue with BAPI_PRODORDCONF_CREATE_TT / CREATE_HDR – Confirmation Saved but Not Visible in CO15
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I’m working on a .NET solution using the SAP .NET Connector (NCo) to confirm and update production orders and their operation quantities (yield, scrap, and rework).

I’m using the following BAPIs:

  • BAPI_PRODORDCONF_CREATE_TT

  • BAPI_PRODORDCONF_CREATE_HDR

I’m updating the TIMETICKETS table for BAPI_PRODORDCONF_CREATE_TT and the ATHDRLEVELS table for BAPI_PRODORDCONF_CREATE_HDR, setting all relevant field values.

When I execute these BAPIs, I receive a success message:
"Confirmation of order [OrderId] saved."

However, when I check transaction CO15, the confirmation is created, but the values are not the same as those I passed to the BAPI functions. Only the yield is recorded, and it reflects the total planned output quantity of the production order, rather than the specific quantities (yield, scrap, rework) that I provided during execution.

I’m committing the transaction using:

BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT
f.SetValue("WAIT", "X");
f.Invoke(dest);

(dest is an RfcDestination)

I get the same result when testing these functions in transaction SE37.

What am I missing or doing wrong?

Thanks for your help!

entry.title: Henkel：借助SAP Business AI实现贸易促销管理转型
entry.content:
如果您对BTP感兴趣，BTP个人精选内容目录 | SAP Blogs 可能有更多你需要的内容

本文内容来自Link

 

案例概览

Henkel是一家拥有145年历史的跨国工业制造和消费品公司，在全球拥有48,000名员工。面对数字化转型挑战，公司与SAP深度合作开展Digital Leapfrog项目，基于SAP Analytics Cloud的生成式AI能力构建贸易促销管理(TPM)和优化(TPO)工具。该方案通过自然语言交互和智能推荐引擎，将原本需要数月完成的促销活动规划缩短至一周内完成，大幅提升了客户经理的工作效率和决策质量。

 

客户评价

"我们与SAP专注于共同创新，为我们的特定业务挑战开发数字化解决方案。我们正在共同为Henkel创造竞争优势。"

——Markus Hartmann，Henkel AG & Co. KGaA业务技术主管兼欧洲、亚太及IMEA地区负责人

 

关键量化提升

  • 20亿规划节点支持
  • 年管理10万次促销
  • 促销规划提速90%

 

Before: Challenges and opportunities

  • 数字化滞后：传统CPG行业在数字技术采用方面缓慢，与客户需求之间存在日益扩大的脱节
  • 人才短缺：缺乏数据科学家、数据工程师和AI专家等关键技术人才，难以推进数字化转型战略
  • 工具缺失：市场上缺乏标准化的贸易促销管理方案，现有工具无法处理复杂的数据模型和大规模计算需求
  • 流程低效：促销活动规划流程复杂耗时，需要数月时间才能确定合适的折扣策略和活动细节

 

Solution

  • 战略合作：与SAP建立深度战略合作关系，基于SAP BTP平台开展Digital Leapfrog共同创新项目
  • AI驱动工具：构建基于生成式AI的贸易促销管理和优化工具，集成SAP Analytics Cloud的Just Ask功能
  • 自然语言交互：通过生成式AI实现自然语言驱动的分析功能，让非数据科学专业人员也能轻松使用AI能力
  • 智能推荐引擎：利用机器学习技术构建推荐引擎，帮助用户实时进行贸易促销优化决策

 

After: Value-driven results

  • 规模处理：成功满足了超过20亿个规划节点的大规模数据处理和分析需求
  • 效率提升：促销活动规划时间从数月缩短至一周内完成，工作效率显著提升
  • 决策智能化：客户经理可实时使用自然语言探索促销方案，次日即可形成完整计划
  • 业务优化：贸易促销的边际优化对公司营收和利润产生巨大积极影响，提升整体竞争力

 

数字化转型战略

  • 组织重构：重新调整IT组织架构，创建新的数字化部门，将CIO和CDO职能合并统一管理
  • 全球布局：在柏林、上海、班加罗尔和美国等关键枢纽城市建立全球创新中心
  • 人才策略：通过内部大规模技能提升和外部人才引进相结合的方式，构建数字化人才队伍
  • 五年规划：制定明确的五年数字化转型战略路线图，将软件、数据和AI能力作为核心要素

 

未来AI战略愿景

  • 领域专用LLM：将CPG研发数据转化为大语言模型，加速新产品开发并建立行业领导地位
  • 垂直化AI应用：相信垂直领域的专用LLM将成为巨大竞争优势
  • 价值链重构：通过率先构建行业LLM，在整个价值链重构过程中获得市场主导权和话语权
  • 竞争优势构建：将生成式AI作为未来战略愿景的核心构建模块，而非仅仅用于业务优化

entry.title: SAP Joule AI copilot integration with SAP Successfactor -lesson learned
entry.content:
SAP Joule AI copilot integration with SAP Successfactor

Recommended links for SAP joule activation and implementation

https://discovery-center.cloud.sap

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-btp-onboarding-series-joule-getting-started-with-joule-and-sap/ba-p/13575477

Refer the blogs from nageshcaparthy Product and Topic Expert from SAP

 

 

 

Comparison of SAP Jule copilot with others for understanding. A nice one taken during one lecture.

Feature

SAP Joule

Microsoft Co pilot

Google Duet

Core Focus

Entire Enterprise process

365 Dynamics

Its workplace kind of tool

Native Integration

S4HANA, SAP SAC, SAP Ariba, SAP Concur, SAP DataSphere etc..

MS Apps+Azure

Google Apps, Vertex AI

Data Context

Strong Data Foundation

Recent actions

Semi Business process

Custom Model

SAP trained + partner LLM

Open AI

PaLM2

 

 

Important point to consider before activation of Joule : Ensure that region where the joule subaccount will be activated should be same as SAP Start too.

Joule supported DC’s

https://help.sap.com/docs/joule/serviceguide/data-centers-supported-by-joule

In our scenario joule subaccount is region EU30 where as SAP Start is in region EU20 you will face the below error

SAP Start is available in below regions

https://help.sap.com/docs/start/sap-start/data-center-availability

 

 

 

 

In above situations where SAP Joule and SAP start are in different regions and only resolve is you need to drop the subaccount and recreate in a region supported by both i.e we selected EU20.

Some constraints of SAP Joule

https://help.sap.com/docs/joule/integrating-joule-with-sap/constraints-for-joule

 

 

 

 

One more important aspect of SAP joule implementation in SAP Successfactor is that you need to ensure that SAP Successfactor is integrated with SAP IAS with SSO. If you have not done this then you can follow the below link for the same which includes activation of SAP People Analytics.

https://community.sap.com/t5/human-capital-management-blog-posts-by-members/how-to-enable-stories-in-people-analytics-for-sf-systems-provisioned-before/ba-p/13644586

A proper planning is needed on how the users are replicated into IAS which will act as a HUB for central user store for integration of SAP Joule with other SAP Products like SAP SF, SAP Ariba, SAP SAC, SAP Concur, SAP Datasphere.

It is mandatory requirement by Joule that whichever the SAP products you are planning to integrate should be available in the same IAS tenant. If you already have a such IAS instance where SAP cloud products application are configured with SSO ( Assuming that IAS is already integrated with your ADFS )  and users have a unique Global ID maintained.

Global user ID plays a critical part in complete implementation of Joule and it should be same in both SF and IAS. If you are using IAM as the central user store and all the users are replicated into it from SAP SF.

 

There are 2 options on how you can maintain a unique global ID for users in IAS ..

Option 1: Replicate the users from SAP SF into IAS and further IAS will be used to replicate the same and required users to other SAP cloud products.

Option 2: If your landscape doesn’t have SAP SF then create users in IAS and replicated to other SAP Cloud products.

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/import-or-update-users-for-specific-application

once joule integration with SF is completed you can proceed with configuring the use cases.

Below are couple of issues during this integration process..

 

Issue of content creation is resolved by following SAP note -3638058 - [SuccessFactors Joule Configuration] get <Connectivity/Unauthorized>: Could not fetch the content from the design-time destination. XXX> Error when running SF Content Channel in Work Zone

 

This was due to sfapi credentials which were updated again at sf and destination dt.

 

 

How to activate the use cases in SF

https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-platform/setting-up-and-using-joule-in-sap-successfactors/use-cases-supported-in-joule

use cases supported by joule

 

If any use cases are not available at SF create incident with SAP.

A proper plan needed before rolling out. consideration of the number of messages allowed. Once you reach the limit you will be charged accordingly.

Number messages allowed are as mentioned below.

 

SAP working on rolling out SAP Joule across all Cloud products. Even though there is documentation available  but during implementation there are integration issues.

entry.title: Re: A New Paradigm for Enterprise AI: In-Context Learning for Relational Data
entry.content:
Hi @MKreitlein,

Great question - and you’re right, SAP Analytics Cloud already offers strong predictive capabilities for structured data and defined use cases.

What’s new with SAP-RPT-1 is the paradigm: instead of building separate models for each task, a single pre-trained model can adapt to many use cases through in-context learning - without retraining or scenario setup. It opens up new ways to apply AI across business data at scale, and there’s more to come as we continue expanding on SAP-RPT-1’s potential. We envision the model to play a key role for other SAP products and technologies. Stay tuned for updates down the line.


Best, Markus

entry.title: Migrating Point-to-Point Asynchronous Scenarios Using the Migration Tool in SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
This blog post is part of the series Master Blog: SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite Migration – Tool and Guidance exploring how to migrate various integration patterns from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite using the Migration Tool. In this blog, we will focus on the Point-to-Point (P2P) Asynchronous pattern, which is one of the most common and fundamental integration scenarios.

 

Objective

The goal of this blog is to explain how the Migration Tool supports P2P asynchronous integrations, including:

  • Key configuration options and technical considerations
  • Best practices to ensure reliable and decoupled communication
  • How to implement JMS decoupling and Idempotent Processing effectively

 

Understanding the Point-to-Point Asynchronous Pattern

In a Point-to-Point (P2P) asynchronous integration, a message is sent from a sender to a receiver without a response message. This pattern promotes decoupling between systems, improves reliability, and allows retry mechanisms to ensure delivery in case you are using JMS queues. By default, the Migration Tool will enable JMS queues during migration.

If there are constraints on the limit of available JMS queues, the tool also supports direct communication without JMS, though this reduces decoupling and resilience. If you are migrating a high number of asynchronous interfaces, SAP recommends using the pipeline approach, which will not be covered in this blog. You can find more information in Pipeline Concept and  Migration Tooling now supporting migration via the pipeline approach.

 

Migration Tool Support for P2P Asynchronous Scenarios using Standard Approach

The Migration Tool automates most of the effort by generating a ready-to-use Integration Flow (iFlow) and the corresponding configuration objects in SAP Cloud Integration.

Depending on your settings, the tool can generate Integration Flows that:

1. Decouple with JMS Queue: Use JMS queues for decoupling between sender and receiver systems (only shown for Asynchronous interfaces):

When you select this option, the Migration Tool creates two Integration Processes within the generated iFlow:

  • Inbound Process
    • Receives the message from the migrated Sender Component and Communication Channel
    • Forwards the message to the JMS queue
  • Outbound Process
    • Reads the message from the JMS queue
    • Performs any required processing (e.g., message mapping, data transformation)

Delivers the message to the receiver system

Please note that you need to maintain the name of the JMS queue post-migration using the already created external parameters:

2. Idempotent Process at the Receiver Side: Use the idempotent process call if you want to make sure that the message will be delivered exactly once to the target system:

When you select this option, the generated iFlow will include an Idempotent Process Call. This mechanism ensures that a message is delivered exactly once to the receiver system, avoiding duplicate postings.

The API call at the receiver system is wrapped then into this local integration process.

There are receiver adapters that do supports idempotency such as SOAP RM, XI and IDoc. In these cases, it’s preferable that you don’t use the Idempotent option on Migration Tool and choose to handle it directly in the adapter. You can find more information in Special Use Cases: SAP RM vs XI vs IDoc.

 

Post-Migration Activities and Special Scenarios

While the Migration Tool significantly accelerates the transition from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite, a few manual fine-tuning steps are typically required.

Generic Post-Migration Steps

After migrating a P2P Asynchronous interface:

  1. Review and update external parameters for sender and receiver connectivity.
  2. Define the JMS queue name to be used in both Integration Processes (in case checkbox is marked during wizard). This can be done in the external parameters’ configuration view.
  3. Update
  4. Review if you want to change the value of the header SAP_Sender according to the naming convention that will be adopted on SAP Integration Suite.

Manual Activities Depending on Integration Scenario

You can also find below few examples of manual activities post-migration that needs to be performed depending on the content of your integration scenario:

  1. Functions like RFC Lookup or JDBC Lookup on Graphical Message Mapping are not automatically converted. Replace them with equivalent Integration Suite adapters or externalized APIs. Tutorials are available for JDBC lookups and RFC lookups.
  2. If your interface is using any custom code (e.g., UDF, Function Library, Java Mapping) or XSLT that have additional dependencies, Therefore, you need to export them from SAP Process Orchestration and import into your Integration Flow
  3. If your interface is using a fault message handling, this won’t be migrated using the Migration Tool. Therefore, you need to import the mapping using the standalone functionality and add an exception handling subprocess into the migrated iFlow

Please refer to the Known Limitations of Migration Tooling for additional insights into cases that may require manual adjustments after migration. we will explore specific topics in more depth, such as XSLT transformation differences between SAP Process Orchestration and SAP Integration Suite, custom code migration, fault message handling, and other advanced migration scenarios.

 

Async-Sync Bridge Support

The Point-to-Point Asynchronous pattern also covers scenarios using an Async-Sync bridge.

In SAP Process Orchestration, an asynchronous interface is converted into synchronous using the RequestResponseBean module, enabling a response message to be sent back to the sender asynchronously using a second interface object.

The Migration Tool can migrate this Async-Sync bridge scenario as well, ensuring that both asynchronous and synchronous steps are merged into a single iFlow.

Please note that the Sync-Async bridge scenario (the opposite from the above), is not supported as of today.

 

Conclusion

In this first blog of the blog series, we explored how to migrate Point-to-Point Asynchronous scenarios and how the Migration Tool simplifies this process by leveraging JMS decoupling and Idempotent Processing. These capabilities help ensure reliable, scalable, and fault-tolerant communication between systems.

entry.title: Java Integration Failures After SAP BTP’s DigiCert G5 Root Certificate Adoption – A Practical Fix
entry.content:
Background

Around seven days ago, SAP replaced its old root certificate, DigiCert Global Root G2, with DigiCert Global Root G5. This change was part of a regular security renewal on SAP’s side — but it caught many Java based applications off guard.

Operating system level trust stores were updated in line with instructions received. But...
While browsers and Windows applications updated their trust automatically, Java runtimes did not.
That’s where things got interesting.

The Symptom

One of our external systems, running on Red Hat OpenJDK — suddenly stopped sending messages to SAP ECC via BTP Integration Suite.

The log showed this familiar (but dreaded) exception:

 
javax.net.ssl.SSLHandshakeException: PKIX path building failed: sun.security.provider.certpath.SunCertPathBuilderException: unable to find valid certification path to requested target

Classic SSL trust failure — and in this case, caused by a missing root certificate.

The Analysis

The new DigiCert Global Root G5 certificate was trusted by Windows but missing in the OpenJDK truststore (cacerts).

Unlike browsers or OS components, this particular JRE maintains its own internal truststore — it doesn’t inherit the operating system’s trusted certificate authorities.

So while everything else trusted the new SAP certificate, the Java runtime didn’t recognize it — and refused to connect.

The Practical Fix

1️⃣ Backup the existing truststore

cd <path_to_redhat_openjdk>\jre\lib\security copy cacerts cacerts.bak

2️⃣ Download the DigiCert Global Root G5 certificate

Get it directly from DigiCert’s official repository:
https://knowledge.digicert.com/generalinformation/digicert-root-and-intermediate-ca-certificates

Save it as g5.cer.

3️⃣ Import the certificate into Java’s truststore

..\..\bin\keytool -importcert -file g5.cer -keystore cacerts -alias "DigiCertG5" 

Default password: changeit
Confirm when prompted.

4️⃣ Verify the import

..\..\bin\keytool -list -keystore cacerts -storepass changeit | find "DigiCertG5"

5️⃣ Restart your application

Restart any Java processes using that truststore.

✅ Result: SSL handshake succeeded.
✅ Message flow from JAVA APP → BTP IS → SAP ECC restored.

 

Lessons Learned

  1. Java ≠ Browser.
    Java doesn’t automatically inherit trusted roots from your OS.

  2. Certificate renewals ripple.
    Cloud platforms like SAP BTP periodically renew CAs — and your Java apps might silently fail afterward.

  3. Test from the runtime, not Chrome.
    Always validate SSL using the same Java runtime your integration runs on.

  4. Keep a “trust refresh” procedure.
    Maintain a documented, repeatable way to update and verify truststores.

  5. Automate where possible. If you manage multiple runtimes, script the import and verification steps.

 

The Bigger Picture

Integration is all about trust — both technically and organizationally.
A single missing certificate can bring down a perfectly built integration chain.

This incident was a reminder: even when nothing changes in your code, something always changes in the environment. And sometimes, that enough to break trust.

entry.title: Lifecycle Management enhancements you don’t want to miss in SAP Business One SP 2511 !
entry.content:
If you administrate SAP Business One systems or handle lifecycle management operations - this one’s for you !

The latest Support Package (SP 2511) brings meaningful upgrades across Lifecycle Management, strengthening identity management, refining security, and simplifying system operations.

Here’s a quick roundup of what’s new:

Identity & Authentication Management (IAM)

The Identity and Authentication Management guide now includes two key updates designed to make authentication more seamless and secure:

  • Principal Propagation via Azure Apps
    SAP Business One now supports authentication of user context coming from Microsoft Azure based applications. The propagated identity is securely passed into SAP Business One, allowing partner applications to access system resources without additional sign-ins. 
    📖  To learn more about Principal Propagation via Azure Apps, refer to this chapter under Identity and Authentication Management guide
  • Single Sign-On with AD FS
    Ever wished you could sign in to the Web Client using your Windows SSO?
    Users with Active Directory Federation Service (AD FS) accounts can now enable SSO by configuring browsers to use Windows Integrated Authentication, making the login experience faster and frictionless. 
    📖  For step-by-step instructions, see the dedicated     chapter under Identity and Authentication Management guide



Server Tools: Dedicated Tomcat Instances
As the saying goes, “Good things come in small packages"...In this case, separating Tomcat instances means smoother restarts, fewer conflicts, and a faster SAP Business One backend.
SP 2511 introduces a modular Tomcat architecture for core components, allowing each service to be restarted or redeployed independently for greater flexibility and uptime.
Here's the breakdown for component configuration in SP 2511:

  • For SAP Business One (MS SQL)

    Component / ServiceDefault Port Description
    SAP Business One Server Tools Service (64-bit)40000

    Hosts System Landscape Directory (SLD) and Extension Manager 

    SAP Business One License Service (64-bit)40002Dedicated Instance for License Service
    SAP Business One Job Service (64-bit)40004Runs Job Service (and embedded MS365 Integration)
    ℹ️   You need to update the redirect URI for Microsoft 365 Integration after upgrading SAP Business One to 10.0 SP 2511 as Microsoft 365 Integration is installed with Job Service.
    SAP Business One Service Layer Controller (64-bit)40005Runs Mobile Service and Service Layer Configuration Manager
    ℹ️  This change applies exclusively to the Service Layer Configuration Manager. The port numbers for the Service Layer Load Balancer and Service Layer Nodes remain unchanged

  • For SAP Business One (Version for HANA)

    Component / ServiceDefault Port Description
    sapb1servertools.service40000

    Hosts System Landscape Directory (SLD), Extension Manager and Backup Service

    sapb1servertools-license.service40002Dedicated Instance for License Service
    sapb1servertools-analytics.service
    		40003Runs Analytics Service
    sapb1servertools-jobservice.service40004Runs Job Service (and embedded MS365 Integration)
    ℹ️   You need to update the redirect URI for Microsoft 365 Integration after upgrading SAP Business One to 10.0 SP 2511 as Microsoft 365 Integration is installed with Job Service.
    sapb1servertools-servicelayercontroller.service40005Runs Mobile Service and Service Layer Configuration Manager
    ℹ️  This change applies exclusively to the Service Layer Configuration Manager. The port numbers for the Service Layer Load Balancer and Service Layer Nodes remain unchanged

ℹ️  Note:
During installation (or upgrade from versions earlier than SP 2511), port numbers can be configured directly in the setup wizard via dedicated panes or during reconfigure.
Make sure to review and adjust your network, firewall, and high-availability settings to match the new port configuration.
(As part of this restructuring, the default port for License Manager and License Control Center is updated from 40000 to 40002.
Administrators configuring high availability need to adjust settings to ensure seamless integration with the new setup).



Platform Matrix Updates
Here's what's new under supported Matrix for SAP Business One (MSSQL and Version for HANA):

Newly supported:

  • Microsoft Windows Server 2025
  • SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 15 SP7 (x86_64)
  • SAP HANA Enterprise Edition 2.0 SPS 08 Revision 087 (SAP HANA Client Version 2.25.31)

No longer supported:

  • SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 15 SP4 

ℹ️  Note: 
SAP Business One Cloud 1.1 PL21 doesn’t support SAP HANA Enterprise Edition 2.0 SPS 08 Revision 087.



Security Hardening
(Applicable for users that log in to SAP Business One with a company user account - not an IDP account).

By now, you’ve probably noticed the "Refresh"  button under the "Choose/Create Company"  window is gone and you might be wondering why. The reason is simple: it’s all about keeping things safe and controlled!

Here's how it works; If a company database is restored directly on the database server (outside of SAP Business One), it’s now up to the Landscape administrator to refresh the company list centrally via System Landscape Directory (SLD). This ensures that only authorized users can make newly restored companies visible under "Choose/Create Company"  window, reducing unnecessary exposure of system information before users are authenticated.

Internal operations triggered from within SAP Business One, such as company creation, upgrades, or year-end transfers, automatically refresh the company list as part of the workflow, so no additional action required in these scenarios.



Summary

SP 2511 brings smarter IAM, a more flexible modular Tomcat setup, expanded platform support, and tighter security for company databases - all designed to make managing SAP Business One smoother, safer, and more effective in your day-to-day operations.

Thanks for reading this roundup of SP 2511 lifecycle management updates! Hope you find these features valuable and enjoy putting them to work in your daily operations.

entry.title: Re: Unplanned Delivery Cost of Purchasing in S4HANA Cloud, Public Edition
entry.content:
@Qi_Liu  Thanks, Our customer requires that freight (unplanned delivery cost) is handled via a separate purchase order, so the freight supplier receives a distinct PO document. For materials managed at moving average price (MAP) in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, how can we link the freight PO and resulting invoice to the original goods PO/material so the freight cost updates the material’s MAP, rather than posting only to an expense account? Is there a standard configuration or process for this scenario or any practical workaround? Detailed steps or best-practice recommendations would be highly appreciated. Thank you!

As a workaround, we tried the following approach: within the same international purchase order, we created a freight condition type and entered an approximate freight value. We then changed the supplier accordingly.

To handle document printing without confusion, we developed two separate print forms:

International PO – for the main material supplier

Local Freight PO – for the freight supplier

With this setup, the landed cost was correctly added to the material’s moving average price (MAP) after the goods receipt.

However, when attempting to post the invoice for the freight supplier, we were unable to adjust the amount to match the actual freight charges. As a result, the unplanned delivery cost was not added to the material, and the system returned an error message (attached below).

entry.title: Enabling external workflow for Features in SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
We are thrilled to introduce the integration of external workflow for Features in SAP Cloud ALM! It is our newest Change and Deployment Management functionality designed to add custom approval and confirmation steps to the default Feature workflow.

With Feature workflow integration, you can automatically trigger a custom workflow when a Feature’s status changes to ‘Successfully Tested". Custom workflows can be created using external workflow tools, such as SAP Build Process Automation.

In the following example, we will show how to design a custom test confirmation workflow in SAP Build Process Automation (BPA) and enable it for Features in SAP Cloud ALM. When the user triggers the action "Confirm Successful Test" in a Feature, the workflow is automatically started in the BPA instance. A test confirmation request will be sent to the inbox of the dedicated approver. If the request is approved, the Feature status will be set to "Successfully Tested". In case the request is rejected,  the Feature status will stay "In Testing".

Configuration Prerequisites

  • SAP Build Process Automation subscription and the corresponding service instance (including service key) are available.

For more information, please see: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-process-automation/sap-build-process-automation/subscribe-to-sap-build-process-automation

  • SAP Cloud ALM has been provisioned and a Cloud ALM API service instance has been created (including service key)

For more information on how to create a Cloud ALM API service instance, please see: Enabling SAP Cloud ALM API 

Configuration Overview

  • Create destination from SAP Cloud ALM to SAP Build Process Automation
  • Create destination from SAP Build Process Automation to SAP Cloud ALM
  • Define workflow in SAP Build Process Automation
  • Create workflow subscription in SAP Cloud ALM
  • Assign the workflow subscription to a project in SAP Cloud ALM

Create destination from SAP Cloud ALM to SAP Build Process Automation

Logon to your SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) subaccount where your SAP Cloud ALM tenant is provisioned. Navigate to the section Connectivity -> Destinations and create a destination with the following parameter:

Parameter Name Value
Type HTTP
URL https://<url>/workflow/rest/v1/workflow-instances
<url> = URL from the section endpoints -> api of the BPA instance service key
Proxy Type Internet
Authentication OAuth2ClientCredentials
Client ID section uaa->clientid of the BPA instance service key
Client Secret section uaa->clientsecret of the BPA instance service key
Token Service URL Typededicated
Token Service URLhttps://<tenant>.authentication.<domain>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token
for <tenant> and <domain>, please refer to the URL from the section uaa->url of the BPA instance service key

 Create destination from SAP Build Process Automation to SAP Cloud ALM

Logon to your SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) subaccount where your SAP Build Process Automation tenant is provisioned. Navigate to the section Connectivity -> Destinations and create a destination with the following parameter:

Parameter Name Value
Type HTTP
URL https://<your tenant>/api
Proxy Type Internet
Authentication OAuth2ClientCredentials
Client ID section uaa->clientid of the Cloud ALM API instance service key
Client Secret section uaa->clientsecret of the Cloud ALM API instance service key
Token Service URL Typededicated
Token Service URLhttps://<tenant>.authentication.<domain>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token
for <tenant> and <domain>, please refer to the URL from the section uaa->url of the Cloud ALM API instance service key

Add the following additional properties to the destination:

  • sap.applicationdevelopment.actions.enabled = true
  • sap.processautomation.enabled = true

Define workflow in SAP Build Process Automation

Here is an example of a test confirmation workflow including a 4-eyes principle check and email notification to the test approvers:

You can download the example workflow HERE, import it into your SAP Build Process Automation tenant and adjust it to your needs.

Note, that the Feature status switch is done by using the Workflow API. When a workflow is accepted (workflow status COMPLETED), the Feature status will be set to "Successfully Tested". In case a workflow is rejected (workflow status FAILED), the Feature status will remain "In Testing". By using script tasks you can access the contextual information of the workflow and maintain optional attributes like externalApprovers or externalDecision which are maintained in the Feature history when a workflow is executed.

For more information about script tasks, please check the following: https://help.sap.com/docs/workflow-capability/workflow-cloud-foundry/accessing-contextual-information-during-execution-of-script-tasks 

Please ensure that you have created an environment variable of type Destination under the project properties of your workflow project:

At the project deployment you will be asked to map the Cloud ALM API destination (from SAP Build Process Automation to Cloud ALM) to the destination variable:

Create workflow subscription in SAP Cloud ALM

Create a webhook in External API Management

Logon to your SAP Cloud ALM tenant and navigate to External API Management:

Go to Webhooks Management and choose “Add new webhook”:

Enter the following data:

Parameter Name Value
Name<name of the webhook>
Ext Resource TypeWorkflow
Destination SourceBTP destination
Destination Id <id of the destination from SAP Cloud ALM to Build Process Automation tenant>
Destination Type Other

Create mapping

Go to Mappings Management and choose "Add new mapping":

Enter the following data:

Parameter Name Value
Description<name of the mapping>
Version1.0
SourceSAP Cloud ALM
Destination SAP Build Process Automation
Mapping TypePayload Based

Download the example mapping HERE and use it to define the mapping rules.

For more information about mandatory and optional mapping, please check the corresponding sections of the Feature Workflow API guide: https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-alm/apis/configuration-steps-for-workflow-api-for-features 

Add a subscription in External API Management

Go to Subscriptions Management and choose “Add new subscription”.

Enter the following data:

Parameter Name Value
Name<name of the subscription>
Description<description of the subscription>
TypeBuilt-in
Resource TypeWorkflow
Webhook <name of the webhook you created before>
Mapping <name of the mapping you created before>
User Variable NameworkflowDefinitionId
User Variable Value<workflow id>

To get the workflow ID, logon to your SAP Build Process Automation tenant, navigate to Control Tower and go to the tile Environments. Choose the environment where you deployed your workflow. Go to Processes and Workflows, choose your workflow and copy the ID:

This is how the example subscription looks like:

Assign the workflow subscription to a project in SAP Cloud ALM

Navigate to a project for which you want to use the Feature workflow and go to the Subscriptions tab. Assign the already created workflow subscription to the Feature entity:

You are now able to execute test confirmations for Features in SAP Cloud ALM by using SAP Build Process Automation.

entry.title: Re: Effortless SAPUI5 Patch Management: Introducing the New SAPUI5 Runtime Repository
entry.content:
@Marian_Zeis 
Those questions are difficult to answer and first a big disclaimer:
The following is not an official roadmap and you cannot derive any promises or guarantees for the future. Plans are subject to change!

To start with what is possible right now:

  • You will never be able to specify a minor or patch version to run with. Trying this on the ABAP stack, is not supported or allowed
  • There is no SAPUI5 2.0 available, that could be installed at all.

Therefore the answer to all questions is currently: No

Now about the future:

  • There might be a SAPUI5 2.0, which would then be installed on the ABAP system
  • The bootstrap URL from which the UI5 runtime is served can be enhanced with one segment specifying the major version. This can then be used for apps outside FLP in their bootstrap tag.
  • The schema of the manifest.json has already been enhanced that sap.ui5/dependencies/minUI5Version can be an array, specifying multiple min versions, one per supported major version. I.e. apps can express which major versions they support.
  • In FLP it would be up to the system to decide which runtime version is used, based on the specified supported major versions. 

I do not know what you mean with the last question. Could you clarify this?
In general a major version switch is an incompatible change and apps must be ready for this. I.e. there can't be a global setting which affects all apps at once.

entry.title: SAPUI5 application in Build Workzone with CAP Application as a proxy to the backend returns 403
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I have a scenario that seems to be quite common, but I'm failing to find why exactly the integration between the SAPUI5 and a CAP microsservice is not working. In what follows there are some details:

  • I have a CAP application with an approuter that will act as a intermediate between a simple customized table with data of things that relate to a specific customer. In the backend, there is a configuration that maps an user email with the customer that will be used. The backend itself is a OData service exposed through integration suite. This project was created with the CAP template in Business Application Studio. This part is working pretty much fine: i can access the instance of the CAP service with the approuter from a browser
  • I have a SAPUI5 application which has its own lifecycle, so it lives in a separate repository than the CAP microsservice. This application is hosted in SAP Build Workzone, standard edition, and the objective is to forward any request to the backend to the CAP Microssservice as a proxy to the backend that adds the user ID information (i.e., the email of the logged in user) seamlessly to retrieve data in the backend without the user even knowing that this is happening .

The CAP service works like a charm if I call the endpoint from the Browser:

And now, I want to be able to call this same endpoint from my SAPUi5 application that is hosted in SAP Build workzone. I have seen the documentation of Build Workzone  and went through some tutorials, but all of them shows the case when the UI is deployed altogether with the CAP service in the same repository, which unfortunately is not my case. 

I have went through a lot of blog posts and other questions that looked like a similar error was happening, but I had no luck in fixing so far.

 

Here's my understanding:

  • The CAP app has two service instances managed within its mta: gt-customer-portal-access-auth (technical name xsuaa, plan application) and gt-customer-portal-access-auth (technical name destination, plan lite). They are both binded to the approuter and to the CAP generated service, so it looks good
    below is the MTA of the CAP service:

    in xs-security.json, I have the following: 
    {
      "xsappname": "gt-customer-portal-access-gt-br-${space}",

    # service-plan: application
    - name: comvendorcustomermaterialorigin-repo-host
    type: org.cloudfoundry.managed-service
    parameters:
    service: html5-apps-repo
    service-name: comvendorcustomermaterialorigin-html5-service
    service-plan: app-host
    parameters:
    deploy_mode: html5-repo
    enable-parallel-deployments: true

  • Note that it refers to the same xsuaa service as in gt-customer-portal-access-auth.

The problem is that when I open the app in build Workzone, the medatada call for the service returns 403 forbidden without even reaching the app router (I Believe so as there is no logs in the service instance, so it's a bit odd)

Note that i have added a call to the service "whoami" as a test service that is in the CAP application and it's returning 404, and if i uncomment this part of the MTA and redeploy:

  • # - Authentication: OAuth2UserTokenExchange
    # Name: customer_Brasil_GT_CAP_BE
    # URL: https://fb031469trial-dev-gt-customer-portal-access.cfapps.us10-001.hana.ondemand.com
    # Type: HTTP
    # ProxyType: Internet
    # forwardAuthToken: true
    # existing_destinations_policy: update

it also returns 403 now:

I am not sure exactly what needs to be done either in CAP or in the SAPUI5 setup, as it looks like the CAP setup is OK, and most of the documents/blogs says that a destination in BTP level should be enough for the Build workzone approuter to connect to the CAP service. I have this destination setup as below:

Does anyone have gone a similar requirement and managed to make it work? I'm thinking that the approuter generated with my cap app can be the culprit but i'm not sure.

I also checked mostly the capire documents (which always uses the samples of UI5 along with CAP at the same deployment) and the documentation of Build Workzone (mainly https://help.sap.com/docs/build-work-zone-standard-edition/sap-build-work-zone-standard-edition/developing-html5-applications-and-extensions?locale=en-US and other related topics), but I still had no luck on making it work. There is also a sample in https://github.com/SAP-samples/cap-sflight but it uses an approuter from the SAPUI5, which I understood that is not the case when deployng the application to SAP Build Workzone, standard edition (looks like it has its own approuter).

Really appreciate any inputs,

Erick Grilo.

entry.title: Second Half 2025 Release: The Latest Enhancements in SAP SuccessFactors Learning
entry.content:
The second half 2025 release brings a host of new enhancements across the entire SAP SuccessFactors HCM portfolio. In this blog, we'll discuss the key highlights of what we are delivering for the SAP SuccessFactors Learning solution. As always, if you are eager for more, be sure to check out the ‘What’s New Viewer’. 

Manager view enhancements:

Building on the innovations rolled out in both the 2H 2024 and 1H 2025 releases, we are excited to announce additional enhancements to the manager view. Managers will now be able to manage admin assignment due dates, based on configuration, to allow managers who are in charge of their teams' training assignments to update specific due dates without additional admin intervention. This gives managers greater flexibility to adjust deadlines based on specific needs whether those items are part of a curricula or a free floating assignment. Manager experience has also been enhanced to allow for easier identification of team members by including the ID and organizational information of each employee and more seamless navigation of the team hierarchy view. 

Manager due date change

iContent Management Tool rollout:

iContent Management is a new system tool that allows admins to view and delete content stored in the iContent server, meaning it is no longer necessary to directly access the iContent server to view and delete content. Admins will also be able to view course affiliations of each stored content file and schedule content deletion and course cleanup, all from one tool. 

iContent Management tool admin page

Ongoing Enhancements     

As with every release, this is just a snippet of the enhancements and innovations we are delivering across Learning and the full SAP SuccessFactors HCM suite. For full details, please check out the 2H 2025 Release Highlights Resources: 

  • 2H 2025 Release Highlights Brochure
  • 2H 2025 Release Highlights Video 
  • 2H 2025 Release Highlights News Article 
  • Product Release & Road Map Information

Learn more about SAP SuccessFactors Learning.

entry.title: Re: 2H 2025 Release Highlights of SAP Best Practices for SAP SuccessFactors Time Management
entry.content:
Hello @bernardo_jas ,

thanks a lot for your feedback!

Please see below answers to your questions:

  • "Changes to Maternity Leave - is it not possible to make this available for other countries?"
    The rules/picklist/custom fields delivered here are for the concrete use case of maternity leave Germany. From a high-level perspective, it can be taken over for other countries where the behavior of maternity leave is similar, and adapted accordingly to fit to that country. If you have suggestions for a particular country, that is already in scope for Best Practices Time Management, please let us know. We would take it up based on priorities and capacity.
  • "The Time Statements were already available, right? It was already available in the system."
    Yes, the time statements were already available. We’ve delivered them in the 1H 2025 release, but didn’t create a blog a that time. Therefore we mentioned them in the current blog.
  • "Regarding the control of the number of clockings/clockings. If the required number of clockings/clockings is not made, is there any way to deduct the value of x hours if those clockings/clockings are missing?"
    What do you mean by “Number of clockings/clockings is not made”? Are they not made because the employee forgot to punch or because the employee is on leave? For the use case in which the employee forgot to punch, please refer to KBA: 3313903 - Report for missing Clock in and Clock Out - SAP for Me

Best regards,

Monica and Mohan

entry.title: Re: Can We Download App ID, Reference Information, and Ob...
entry.content:
Good day @byd 

Thank you for your question.

Answer to question 1 on available fields:

They are Document Type, Reference Document Number, Manual Entry Idicator,                                                                          Sources Process, Header Text and Line Item Text and Cost Center. See Display Journal Entries & Entry View for Line Item Display for more details.

Answer to question 2 on adding column:

The answer is yes. You need to enable the fields mentioned in question 1. Thereafter, you need to export them and include them in the file.  See App Extensibility: Display and Manage Journal Entries (Key User) & Display Line Items in General Ledger

Answer to question 3 on alternative app availability:

You should consider using the Journal Entry Analyzer, Manage Journal Entries, Display Document Flow and G/L Account Line Item Browser are alternatives you can consider. Have a look at Journal Entry Analyzer & Manage Journal Entry Templates

Answer to question 4 on workaround:

You can use the standard extensibility. You do not require any ABAP. You can either Use the Custom Analytical Query or use OData service for external reporting. The CDS Views, Journal Entry Item - Read (A2X), Custom Analytical Queries & Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Cloud

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: 3ZB Billing Cost between companies is not working
entry.content:
Good day @adrian321 

Thank you for your question.

You can consult the following references for further details.

Intercompany Billing, Communication Scenarios, How to configure output parameter determination, How to configure output parameter determination for purchase contracts, Set Up Output Parameter Determination for Purchase Order & AIF Monitoring.

To summarise, 3ZB relies on plant-level data for intercompany services valuation and on the SAP_COM_0109 communication scenario for automatic document replication in public cloud. Once you add the plant & Accounting data to the service material, and confirm the intercompany communication and BBP mappings, the purchase order will trigger an EDI message that creates the sales order in the supply ing company. Which then completes the 3ZB process.

Below is a step-by-step guidance:

 First you need to verify your communication arrangement. Open th Communication Arrangements app, ensure SAP_COM_0109 is active in both inbound and outbound tenants.

Make sure the communication user and endpoint URL are correctly paired. Both should be active.

Next step is to check the output parameter determination to ensure your Output type PURCHASING_ORDER is verified. Ensure channel is EDI, Receiver= Supplying company’s BP and form template = YY1_MM_PURCHASE ORDER (as shown in your screenshot). Then confirm the condition-based trigger aligns with your intercompany setup.

Thereafter, validate your Business Partner Setup. For this open the Maintain Business Partner app, each company must be set up as both supplier and customer of the other. Make sure both have valid Sales Area and Purchasing Org data. Make sure the customer and supplier numbers should be cross-referenced correctly.

 Finally, you need to review the message dashboard in the supplying tenant. Open the Manage Dashboard- SAP Application Interface Framework App. Ensure you filter by the Namespace (/INTERCOMPANY), Status (All) and date set to today.

If you don’t find any inboud message, then it wasn’t received which points at a communication issue. If it exists but failed, check the XML payload and partner for errors.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris
